Yeah was thinking about this one as well but full cascade was prevented

CRV had a spectacular liquidation event. Mitch had positions spread across many protocols and it was clear that once one was hit, it would trigger a massive cascade onto the others. By this point he had moved most of his borrowing to Curve lend, which ended up with 10m bad debt. He managed to stave off the inevitable for some time in inventive ways, like incentivising liquidity on fraxlend to bring down utilisation as he was bleeding like crazy there. But he was increasingly hunted - when the market saw him collecting rewards from couch cushions, it was a signal he had no cash left to backstop the positions. afaik some marketmakers (wintermute?) handled the liquidation in a pretty orderly fashion. He then sold a lot of tokens OTC and paid down Curve's bad debt. Liquidation cascade seems the right description.

I think the most interesting part of this would be related to LSTs/LRTs loopoing itself;

Right now, for ETH market neutral products, most yield comes from either looping LSTs/LRTs or lending ETH on money markets.

The thing is, a lot of this lending is backed by LSTs/LRTs, and they most rely on fundamental/exchange rate oracles. As a borrower, thatâ€™s fine (I am not borrowing against market oracle for example)

But as a lender, we havenâ€™t seen a major slashing yet. ...So you might spend 2â€“3 years happily collecting lending yield (2-3%), but all that time youâ€™re really exposed to the looperâ€™s risk...thisif when slash hits, it can flip in a single bloc...you could be suddenly youâ€™re in bad debt territory. 

We havenâ€™t seen real slashing cases in size so far though, and now with Pectra the dynamics are different (Chaos wrote a good post on it).

That's true - I think perhaps that's the extreme case and perhaps a DeFi cascade can be defined as anything where the price decrease gains momentum from liquidations as obviously an avalanche doesn't always make it to the bottom of a mountain. There is always fair value friction

Neverthless, we couldn't really find anything crazy in terms of cascading

that is a very aggressive definition. The lending markets dont often list tokens that have this kind of risk. Biggest catastrophic lending incidents are Geist (AAVE fork on Fantom died due to Anyswap hack) and Blizz (AAVE fork on Avax that died due to Terra/LUNA collapse & price oracle breakdown allowing entire market to be borrowed)
Maybe check MakerDAO in March 2020, I seem to recall there was a cascading event

big examples: Mantra & FTT

On March 12th 2020 Eth dropped 33% in a few hours with over 500 liquidations but even then, compound saw only 16% of its ETH pools wiped out on that day and it very much looked like the price action of global macro driving the assets to a repricing rather than a stressed liquidation cascade in DeFi
Cascading liqudations happen more on perp CEXes is my gut feeling
I think those have not been seen since like 2020 COVID started and DeFi was much smaller then

By liquidity cascades I mean the effect of selling from liquidations being so aggressive that it moves the price down and effectively becomes self fulfilling until the token dumps to 0

Is Terra Luna perhaps an example of this ? I'm not too familiar with the mechanics of that and it's kind of uot of scope given focus on aave, euler, morpho, kamino

Has anyone got any concrete evidence of cascade / liquidity avalanches in DeFi - we've been searching a lot of datasets for and seen little evidence so far.

Only considering permissionless majors and OGs: Aave, Euler, Kamino, Morpho, Gearbox

The only key event that I know of is on Aave with wstETH / ETH around the time of USDC depeg and it was calculated by Lido team if peg hit 92% it would hit a critical cascade effect but that never materialised as the peg didn't drop to that level
